content: UC major mapping creates coherent narrative across campuses. Game design where available (Irvine, Santa Cruz), cognitive science with ML where not (UCSD, Davis), data science as alternative (UCLA, Riverside). Discovery: Student hasn't researched systematically. Jenny probes: 'Would UCSD be a school you want to go to? No point if not.' Genuine interest test prevents wasted applications.

Scholarship specificity formula: 'As specific as possible to you.' Progression: Tech → Women in Tech → Muslim Women in Tech. Perfect find: 'STEM Scholarship for Muslim Women' discovered. Geographic layer: 'Central California Asian Pacific Women.' Jenny insight: Less competition for niche scholarships. Database created with 25+ opportunities across tech companies, gaming, regional, demographic categories.

Live research method deployed: Jenny researches UC majors in real-time during session. UCSD cognitive science with ML specialization found live. Davis computational emphasis discovered together. Student sees actual process not just results. Transparency builds trust. Company name game: 'Name a tech company and we'll check' makes scholarship hunting interactive. Tried OpenAI, Apple, Samsung, Facebook. Systematic exploration beats random searching.

Technical difficulty grace: Huda's computer freezing mid-session, switches to dad's computer. Jenny: 'No worries. Glad you were able to make it back.' Student preference validation: 'Would you want to go there? No point if not.' Respects agency. Parent coordination: 'Talk to your dad about income reporting for financial aid. You don't have to worry about that.' Protects student from financial complexity.

Session pivot: Original plan social media marketing, student requests college applications focus. Jenny immediate adaptation: 'Okay cool, let's look at what you filled in.' Major discovery UCLA challenge: no game design, cognitive science too philosophical. Solution: data science as alternative. Scholarship research pivot: many for college students only, note which ones for later. ISF Media Scholarship saved for college years.

UC application efficiency framework: 'Count as one application for multiple schools.' Strategy: maximize value of single application fee by applying to most UCs. Strategic coverage: range from reach (Berkeley) to safety (Riverside) within one app. Safety school philosophy: 'Only apply where you'd genuinely attend.' Removed CSU Fullerton (far, not interested), kept Cal Poly SLO (actually interested). Backup plan validation: Community college TAG program legitimate not shameful.

Session deliverables: 7 UCs with specific majors identified (Berkeley Media Studies, UCLA Data Science, Irvine Game Design, UCSD Cognitive Science, Davis Cognitive Science, Santa Cruz CS Game Design, Riverside Data Science), Cal Poly SLO and RIT added as safeties, 25+ scholarships documented in database. Quantified targets: 11 applications total (manageable), 25+ scholarships to apply fall-spring. Strategic decisions: no CSU Fullerton, TAG program as backup, delay Common App essay until August.

Live research coordination: UC websites browsed during session, scholarship sites evaluated real-time, Notion editing simultaneous documentation. Resource sharing: students share scholarship finds via chat, evaluate sketchy websites together, collaborative company naming for systematic search. Documentation strategy: type directly into Notion, organized separate databases for different needs, accessible with live updates visible to student.

Website critique shared: 'Scholarship websites look so sketchy. Look at this blue website!' Validation: 'Yeah but they're real scholarships.' Company exploration game makes research fun. Coca-Cola surprise: 'The Coca Cola is really random.' Jenny: 'Yeah, and such a well established one too.' Location flexibility understanding: Rochester 'If I have to, I probably would.' Acknowledges sometimes going where opportunity is.

The One Application Multiple Schools Strategy: UC system provides exceptional value - 7 schools on single application. Jenny frames: 'Count UC as one application.' Psychology: reduces overwhelm (11 apps really 5 unique ones). Strategy: maximize return on investment by applying to most UCs except maybe 1-2. Coverage: reach to safety within one app (Berkeley to Riverside). Efficiency: same essays, same fee, different chances. California advantage: no other state system offers this. Result: comprehensive coverage without application overload.
